awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract

Award: DMS 1623977, Principal Investigator: Haynes R. Miller

This award provides support for the next three Talbot workshops to be held in 2017, 2018, and 2019. Since its initial meeting in 2004, the Talbot Workshop has introduced young researchers in algebraic topology to topics of contemporary interest. This annual workshop gathers about 35 young participants and one or two senior mathematicians for a week-long retreat; the participants, who are mostly graduate students, learn about the week's research topic by exchanging lectures and discussing the topic under the guidance of the mentors. The workshop has been extremely successful, inspiring the future research of many students and establishing numerous collaborations among the participants. The workshop's unique format, in which participants live and cook together in a rental house, helps to create and sustain the collaborative atmosphere.

Past Talbot Workshops have focused on a wide variety of topics in homotopy theory and surrounding areas, from elliptic cohomology (2004) and Fukaya categories (2009) to non-abelian Hodge theory (2011) and, most recently (2016), the Hill-Hopkins-Ravenel solution of the longstanding Kervaire invariant problem (with Hill and Ravenel as mentors). The topics under preliminary consideration for 2017, 2018, and 2019 include: stability conditions on triangulated categories, trace methods in algebraic K-theory, conformal field theory, derived algebraic geometry, applied topology, and Heegaard Floer theory. As many of the participants are first- or second-year graduate students looking to get a start in a promising research area, the lectures begin with basics, such as an introduction to model categories and to equivariant homotopy theory in the 2016 workshop, and lead up to a presentation of open problems related to the workshop material. The web site for the Talbot workshops is http://math.mit.edu/conferences/talbot/.

por.por_cntn:
The Talbot Workshop is an annual retreat which immerses young mathematicians, chiefly graduate students in homotopy theory and algebraic topology, in a topic of current research. The graduate student leadership invites two faculty mentors, who then choose a precise topic and compose a syllabus of between 16 and 18 lectures. Over the course of a week, participants deliver these lectures with the faculty mentors guiding their preparation. Orienting lectures by the mentors provide an expert bird's eye view of the subject and suggest myriad research directions, and many research projects and collaborations have grown out of the workshops. Much of the mathematical activity of the workshop occurs outside of the lectures, either in organized question sessions or spontaneous conversations among the participants and the mentors. NSF funding was used to support travel and local expenses for from 30 to 40 participants at each workshop. 

This grant was written to support the 2017, 2018, and 2019 workshops, but a no cost extension of the grant partially funded a virtual workshop in 2020 and the 2021 and 2022 Talbot Workshops as well. The 2017 Talbot Workshop on Obstruction Theory for Structured Ring Spectra was mentored by Maria Basterra (Professor, University of New Hampshire) and Sarah Whitehouse (Professor, University of Sheffield). The 2018 Talbot Workshop on Model-Independent Theory of Infinity Categories was mentored by Emily Riehl (Associate Professor, Johns Hopkins University) and Dominic Verity (Emeritus Professor, Macquarie University). The 2019 Talbot Workshop on Moduli Spaces of Manifolds was mentored by Soren Galatius (Professor, University of Copenhagen) and Oscar Randall-Williams (Professor, University of Cambridge). The 2021 workshop was mentored by Jacob Lurie (Institute for Advanced Study) and Tomer Schlank (Hebrew University of Jerusalem), on the subject of ambidexterity in chromatic homotopy theory. The 2022 Talbot Workshop was mentored by Jonathan Campbell (Center for Communications Research) and Inna Zakharevich (Cornell University) on the topic of scissors congruence and K-theory. The 2021 and 2022 workshops were held in a hybrid format.


The 2020 virtual conference, entitled Viva Talbot!, departed from the traditional format to allow for broader participation from attendees in a wide range of locations. The conference invited early-career researchers to provide an update on recent work in an area which was the subject of a past Talbot workshop, and to discuss their own work in the context of the field. The program featured ten Zoom talks originating from Australia, France, Germany, Switzerland, and Great Britain, in addition to the US.  

with the (year: topic) referring to their corresponding past Talbot workshop. Viva Talbot! was bookended by plenary lectures by Vesna Stojanoska (UIUC) and Mike Hill (UCLA). Furthermore, the conference aimed to create a sense of community among participants during a time of isolation and lockdowns by holding social activities such as tea times, game nights, and a cook-along. Viva Talbot! saw hundreds of participants from several continents. 

The Talbot Workshops provide an exceptional opportunity for the professional development of young mathematicians. Unlike most other academic conferences, the Talbot Workshop immerses participants in a communal environment. Aside from time explicitly dedicated to discussing mathematics, participants develop a sense of camaraderie while preparing meals and going on hikes. This setting encourages participants to build academic relationships and strengthens the community of young researchers.

The workshops stimulate creation of weekly seminars, in the months leading up to the workshop, at several institutions across the country. It has also inspired other workshops which operate under a similar format: the "European Talbot Workshop" in algebraic topology, and the Kylerrec workshops in symplectic topology.

The Talbot Workshop leadership maintains a website presenting a detailed account of the activities, along with lecture notes by participants and occasionally by a mentor as well. This record of a systematic presentation of an important current research topic has proven to be a valuable resource accessible to all researchers in algebraic topology.

Talbot is also committed to promoting diversity in the mathematical community. The 2017-2019 workshops continued to seek diverse pools of applicants, both in terms of underrepresented minorities as well as institutional diversity. In 2017, 10 out of 36 participants were women and one was non-binary; in 2018, 14 out of 38 participants were women and 2 identified as non-binary; in 2019, 10 out of the 38 participants were women. The 2021 workshop continued this trend with 10 out of 33 participants (including those joining virtually) identifying as female and 2 as non-binary. At the 2022 workshop on Scissors Congruence and Algebraic K-Theory, 9 of the 19 in-person participants identified as female. In addition, three of the six mentors from 2017-2019 were women, and three of the twelve speakers of Viva Talbot! were women. Furthermore, a broad array of institutions were represented among participants in these workshops. In 2019, for example, there were 38 participants from 22 institutions.
